title: The Moments That Mattered in Thursday’s Democratic Debate
text:
The three leading candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination confronted each other over issues including health care in a marathon debate that featured all 10 top contenders onstage for the first time.

Lasting nearly three hours, Thursday’s debate in Houston gave the highest-polling candidates—former Vice President Joe Biden, Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont—their first chance to face off. But the Democrats largely tried to keep the discussion positive, praising the Obama administration and reiterating that they had more in common with each other than with President Trump.

Here were the moments that mattered most:

‘I don’t think that’s a bold idea, I think it’s a bad idea.’

The battle between passion and pragmatism played out early during an exchange over the nation’s health-care system.

Mr. Biden immediately went on the attack against Ms. Warren and her support of a Medicare-for-All plan long promoted by Mr. Sanders. “I know that the senator says she’s for Bernie; well, I’m for Barack,” Mr. Biden said, tying himself to popular former President Obama. “I think the Obamacare worked.”

Mr. Biden called for adding a government-run insurance option to the Affordable Care Act to compete with private plans, suggesting the proposal backed by Ms. Warren and Mr. Sanders is unrealistic, unaffordable and would take private insurance away from tens of millions.

At the third Democratic debate, candidates argued over which health care plan would lower consumer costs the most. Photo: Robyn Beck/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

The former vice president was backed up by Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota. “It says that we will no longer have private insurance as we know it,” she said of the Sanders bill. “That means that 149 million Americans will no longer be able to have their current insurance. That’s in four years. I don’t think that’s a bold idea, I think it’s a bad idea.”

Ms. Warren responded that her policies would be paid for by the wealthiest. “Costs are going to go up for wealthier individuals and costs are going to go up for giant corporations,” she said. “But for hardworking families across this country, costs are going to go down.”

‘A huge debt to President Obama’

Following the last debate in July, allies of Mr. Obama expressed frustration over some candidates’ criticism of the previous administration’s immigration and trade policies. This time candidates were effusive about the former Democratic president even when pushing for more progressive approaches.

“We all owe a huge debt to President Obama, who fundamentally transformed health care in America and committed this country to health care for every human being,” said Ms. Warren as she pushed for Medicare for All, which would replace private insurers with government-run health care.

And former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro —who had criticized Mr. Obama on immigration in the last debate—invoked the former president in contrasting the Castro health-care proposal with Mr. Biden’s more incremental plan. “I’m fulfilling the legacy of Barack Obama, and you’re not,” Mr. Castro said.

‘A house divided cannot stand’

Many Democrats grumbled that the first two primary debates had candidates battling each other rather than contrasting themselves with President Trump. On Thursday, several candidates called for keeping the fight clean and staying unified against the current White House occupant.

The 10 candidates lined up for their introductions. Photo: Eric Gay/Associated Press

When Mr. Biden, Mr. Castro and others talked over each other after the former housing secretary accused the 76-year-old front-runner of “forgetting already what you said just two minutes ago” about his health-care plan, Pete Buttigieg jumped in to play referee.

“This is why presidential debates are becoming unwatchable,” said the mayor of South Bend, Ind.

Mr. Castro shot back: “Yeah, that’s called the Democratic primary election, Pete.”

“A house divided cannot stand,” Ms. Klobuchar replied. “That is not how we’re going to win this.”

The candidates, however, weren’t shy about taking shots at Mr. Trump. “He reminds me of that guy in ‘The Wizard of Oz,’” said Sen. Kamala Harris of California. “When you pull back the curtain, it’s a really small dude.”

‘Hell yes, we’re going to take your AR-15, your AK-47’

Former Texas Rep. Beto O’Rourke, who overhauled his campaign strategy following an August mass shooting in his hometown of El Paso to focus more on gun control, got a standing ovation from some in the audience when he called for a mandatory gun-buyback program.

Although most of the candidates agree on other gun-control measures, Mr. O’Rourke is one of the few to advocate such a plan, which conservatives call a violation of the Second Amendment. Ms. Klobuchar was one of the candidates who said she would support only a voluntary version.

Candidates proposed gun buyback programs and stricter background checks, in the wake of recent mass shootings in Texas and Ohio. They detailed their plans at the third Democratic debate in Houston. Photo: Win McNamee/Getty Images

“Hell yes, we are going to take your AR-15, your AK-47,” Mr. O’Rourke said. “We are not going to allow it to be used against fellow Americans anymore.”

His campaign, which has struggled to gain traction, turned that moment into a fundraising opportunity, tweeting a link to purchase a T-shirt bearing his AR-15 line in red, white and blue.

‘With regard to Iraq…I should have never voted to give Bush the authority to go in’

Mr. Biden recently falsely stated he was against the Iraq war from “the moment it began,” though he voted to authorize the 2003 invasion. On Thursday, he said he shouldn’t have voted that way.

“With regard to Iraq, the fact of the matter is, you know, I should have never voted to give [former President George W.] Bush the authority to go in and do what we said he was going to do,” Mr. Biden said.

The former vice president said that after troops were deployed, he argued against the way the war was conducted—“that in fact we were doing it the wrong way, there was no plan, we should not be engaged, we didn’t have the people with us, we didn’t have our alliance, we didn’t have our allies with us.”

Mr. Sanders wasn’t satisfied, pointing out that he himself voted against authorizing the invasion.

Write to Tarini Parti at Tarini.Parti@wsj.com and John McCormick at mccormick.john@wsj.com
description: The top candidates clashed over health policy, and former Vice President Biden said he was wrong to vote in favor of the 2003 Iraq invasion.
